Nutan \"Newton\" Kumar.Action: Maintains calm and polite demeanor when Mishra laughs at him, responds to teasing with humor.
Clarifies reason for changing name from Nutan to Newton showing self-awareness and light-heartedness.
Walks up to Mishra when spotting him alone in the canteen, initiates a polite conversation.
Expresses desire to make a difference rather than just earning money, responds politely and listens attentively to Mishra's advice.
Becomes confrontational when Mishra questions his honesty ('Meri imaandaari?').
Smiles politely and forces a smile during a friendly but teasing exchange with Mishra.
Responds to questions about marriage directly and politely.
Does not engage or lead the conversation during the arranged marriage meeting, shows uncertainty or discomfort.
Attempts to engage Lila in conversation politely despite the awkward social setting and his nervousness, tries to ask about her interests.
Feels awkward and fails to smoothly handle the social faux pas of the fly in the tea and cream on his lips, cleaning it awkwardly.
Appears hesitant and nervous during the interaction, does not take control of the conversation confidently initially.
Expresses concern about the girl being underage and uncomfortable with the arranged marriage proposal.
Shows anger toward his father for involving him in the marriage discussion without his consent.
Refuses to accept dowry/money and a motorcycle offered by his parents for the marriage.
Insists on wanting a graduate bride and rejects the idea of marrying under social pressure.
Mentions he will never marry as a reaction to the pressure and social expectation.
Performs mental calculation quickly when prompted about girl's age.
Expresses moral or social objection to marrying a minor, showing awareness and conviction.
Engages in verbal dispute with parents about his marriage preferences, standing firm on wanting a graduate bride.
Appears overwhelmed or frustrated by familial/social pressure, shown by anger looks and desperate statements.
Diligently does his work at his office full of dusty files while colleagues are distracted by a cricket match.

Carefully studies the 'Manual of Protocols for Presiding Officers of Polling Booth' and diagrams for operating the Electronic Voting Machine while eating an apple slowly, demonstrating focus and preparation.
Runs early in the morning and performs stretches, indicating discipline and physical preparation.
Looks disturbed while standing in the balcony and gazing out, showing possible internal doubt or worry but no direct incompetence indicated.
Combs his hair neatly in front of a mirror but then shakes his head and accepts his usual hairdo, indicating care for appearance but no exceptional skill or decisiveness.
Asks intelligent and relevant questions about the security risk percentage, showing curiosity and engagement.
Calmly receives mosquito repellent and complies with preventive advice, demonstrating practical awareness and readiness.
Exchanges greetings confidently and respects the chain of command, indicating social competence and confidence.
Asks informed questions about the area being called Pakistan, showing curiosity and a desire to understand the situation clearly.
Shows disbelief when Krishna says 'Pakistan!' indicating a critical mindset rather than blind acceptance.
Though perturbed along with others after hearing casualty figures, does not panic; maintains composure.
Introduces himself politely and firmly shakes Atma Singh's hand despite Atma Singh's intimidating demeanor.
Responds sternly and without humor to Atma Singh’s joke about his name, showing no small talk or warmth.
Insists on following Collector madam’s instructions about including a BLO despite Atma Singh’s skepticism.
Offers to put Atma Singh's statements in writing to forward to the collector, showing responsibility and formality.
Looks away when Atma Singh stares at him, indicating possible discomfort but no hostility.
Attempts to go towards Priya but is stopped by Atma Singh.
Sits quietly with group during tense moment, follows Atma Singh's lead without complaint, remains calm and observant
Maintains calm and composed while an apparent threat occurs (branch snapping) and follows Atma Singh’s instructions to sit down and watch carefully before proceeding.
Does not take the lead in checking the possible booby trap but defers to Atma Singh and his party for verification and clearance.
Walks cautiously with the group and holds files indicating preparedness.
Newton silently contemplates while others focus on the immediate tension, showing calm and thoughtfulness.
Walks to the Gondi youths to presumably interact or handle the situation proactively.
Insists on following proper voting procedure by checking ID cards before allowing voting.
Questions Atma Singh about the limited voting hours and proactively extends voting time by informing voters they can come until three o'clock.
Glares at Loknath when questioned about backing; shows displeasure at insinuation
Feels sad observing the destroyed village and asks pointed questions about the breaking of homes and displacement of people
Walks carefully around the damaged school, showing concern by signaling others when startled by Maoist graffiti
Engages in polite conversation with Priya and Loknath, listens attentively to Priya's difficulties with teaching, and shares a light-hearted moment with Loknath.
Expresses empathy by responding to Loknath's story about the arranged marriage with 'Yeh to bahut bura hua....'
Engages respectfully and thoughtfully in conversation with Priya and Loknath, listening carefully and responding appropriately.
Asks relevant and clear questions about Priya's teaching and Loknath's English learning, showing curiosity and understanding.
Remains composed and politely responds to awkward social moments without losing confidence.
Comments humorously on Loknath's story idea, teasing him gently.
Playfully tells Loknath not to play cards inside, enforcing rules with a light tone.
Shows amusement and engages with Loknath and Priya in informal social interaction.
Maintains authority by reminding Loknath of suspension rules yet without harshness.
Attempts to help villagers by proposing to send constables to ensure their safe arrival at polling booths.
Firmly insists on his authority over Atma Singh despite resistance.
Initiates a plan to send constables to villagers' settlements to bring them safely despite the boycott, demonstrating awareness and proactive problem-solving.
Asserts his authority as presiding officer to enforce his orders on Atma Singh, showing confidence and command.
Newton looks irritated and cautious but does not immediately escalate the confrontation or try alternative persuasion methods, possibly indicating limited coping strategies in a tricky situation.

Stops short of effectively countering Atma Singh's refusal and bureaucratic obstruction, remaining mostly reactive and astounded by the subversion, signaling a gap in dealing with entrenched local power dynamics.
Insists on preventing election fraud, states 'Main apni duty kar raha hoon.'
Responds patiently to Atma Singh's teasing and question about age.
Politely allows Lakhma to ask a sensitive question and listens.
Emphatically refuses to take bribes when questioned about increasing salary unethically.
Insists on not allowing rigging in elections and commits to doing his duty honestly.
Fails to correctly solve a basic math problem (two plus two divided by two) showing a misunderstanding of order of operations.
Responds calmly and clearly when questioned about his age and the relevance of that information, showing self-assuredness.
Demonstrates straightforwardness by refusing to take bribes and questioning the logic behind salary doubling schemes.
States confidently that this is not a fake election, showing awareness and conviction.
Advises trying a remedy against mosquitoes despite doubts, showing pragmatic problem-solving and concern for health risks.
Responds confrontationally when challenged about taking action, indicating confidence but possibly impatience or rigidity.
Laughs along with Priya, takes and eats an ant she offers despite hesitation, engages in light, friendly conversation.
Acknowledges Priya's pointed question about authority with a thoughtful, struck reaction, showing openness to reflection.
Provides simple, neutral responses without dismissiveness when Priya shares local beliefs and experiences.
Hesitates but then tries eating an ant given by Priya, showing open-mindedness and willingness to learn from local practices.
Acknowledges Priya's point about local knowledge gap with a thoughtful response ('mulls' and 'Baat aapki sahi hai...').
Responds lightly and laughs at Priya's ant treatment suggestion, showing some skepticism about unconventional methods.
Appears puzzled by boys singing, showing distraction or lack of attention to surroundings at that moment.
Objects to Atma Singh speaking harshly to children; defends the children against mistreatment.
Questions Atma Singh's treatment of children, shows concern for their well-being.
Looks furious watching Atma Singh threaten the boy, but remains polite and respectful in his tone.
Declares firmly that the policemen are not servants to Atma Singh, defending their dignity.
Does not intervene aggressively or escalate conflict despite witnessing coercion and intimidation towards the child.
Keeps calm and polite while confronting Atma Singh’s intimidation, showing confidence and respectful assertiveness.
Shows moral clarity by standing up against misuse of power, indicating strong situational understanding.
Remains observant and thoughtful, writing furiously at his table, suggesting diligence and focus.
Does not escalate confrontation aggressively, choosing respect over direct conflict, which may limit influence in a hostile environment.
Asks Loknath and Priya detailed questions to clarify timeline despite their discomfort.
Ignores Loknath's question about complaint, continues writing focused on task.
Questions Priya about her skepticism, indicating engagement and concern.
Carefully questions Loknath about exact times, writes furiously, focuses intently on gathering precise information despite interruptions.
Ignores Loknath's comment about writing a complaint, showing focused determination rather than distraction.
Shows signs of being at his wit’s end, indicating some frustration or difficulty managing the situation effectively.
Irritated by dialogues from the film playing nearby, showing low tolerance for distraction.
Responds respectfully and promptly to superior officer Verma, showing professionalism and sincerity.
Looks jubilant at Atma Singh’s arrival and takes initiative to organize his team with a map drawn on the ground.
Responds promptly and respectfully to IG Verma's calls, shows awareness of the situation by reporting zero votes and noting issues with order compliance.
Shows irritation at distractions (film dialogues) but remains focused on his duties, indicating good concentration and self-control.
Jubilantly takes the initiative in directing his men and drawing a rough map to organize forces in preparation for IG Verma's inspection.
Declines the idea of forcing voters to come, insists participation should be voluntary.
Refuses to use force to bring voters, insisting participation should be voluntary and election-focused only.
Appears a bit apprehensive when confronted sarcastically about using force and guns, showing some uncertainty.
Observes the crowd carefully and questions the absence of youth, showing situational awareness and a concern for community participation.
Remains silent and passive in the school while others discuss or act, indicating a lack of overt initiative or leadership in that moment.
Patiently guides villagers through the voting process, gently instructs them on where to stand and how to vote, shows awareness of their nervousness
Addresses villagers patiently and benevolently, encourages questions, and signals others not to scold the drunkard
Explains the voting process clearly and patiently to villagers, including encouraging hesitant questions and maintaining calm control of the situation.
Signals Krishna not to scold the Drunkard, showing self-control and leadership in handling disruptions.
Encourages a hesitant woman to speak up and attempts to explain the importance of voting and leadership to the Adivasi community despite language barriers.
Shows annoyance and frustration when communication difficulties arise, telling Priya to just translate and cooperate.
Tries to facilitate understanding by prompting Priya to translate and read out the candidates’ list to inform the community.
Attempts to explain complex political concepts to illiterate tribal voters but becomes visibly annoyed and struggles when communication breaks down.
Relies heavily on Priya for translation and explanation, indicating limits in his own language and cultural mediation skills.
Recognizes the importance of the election and tries to convey its significance to the voters, showing awareness and intent to do his job correctly.
Asks sincerely 'Kya chahiye hai inhe?' showing willingness to understand the concerns of the locals.
Dismisses Loknath's offer to handle the situation suggesting confidence or perhaps unwillingness to delegate.
Aggressively confronts Atma Singh when he shouts at the Adivasis, showing protection towards the locals against harsh treatment.
Screams at Atma Singh in frustration, but also promises to record everything in his report, indicating a commitment to fairness and accountability.
Supports the crowd against Atma Singh's rude comment and reprimands Atma Singh for power misuse.
Stands up to Atma Singh when he misuses power, speaks firmly against injustice, and attempts to maintain order.
Retreats when faced with Atma Singh’s intimidation instead of escalating conflict or asserting further control.
Sulks and shows extreme unhappiness over the voting process; squirms at EVM sounds and looks away, appearing helpless.
Speaks forcefully despite feeble voice, moves around school to cover voting process diligently.
Insists on waiting for voters even if none show up, emphasizing fairness.
Glares angrily at Loknath and snaps at him to leave.
Invites Priya to speak her mind, showing openness.
Encourages Priya and Shambhu to speak, showing openness and engagement with others' feelings and opinions.
Shows impatience or dismissiveness when responding quickly to Priya's metaphor about patience ('Haan haan, woh maine suna hai... point kya hai aapka?')
Looks at Atma Singh awkwardly but does not refuse the offered food or insult him.
Tries to rush out during the gunshots despite the danger, showing concern and urgency.
Remains mostly expressionless and silent during tense moments, showing emotional reserve.
Sits expressionless and remains composed despite tense and dangerous surroundings.
Tries to rush out during gunfire but is stopped by others cautioning about an ambush.
Shows awareness of the situation by looking at Atma Singh before the gunshots and when Atma Singh shouts instructions.
Unable to exert control over situation or influence events meaningfully, as noted by Atma Singh.
Shows concern for Priya's safety insisting she should not go alone.
Smiles at Priya after a friendly exchange.
Listens to casual conversation and tries to engage Loknath by asking about films.
Engages others with light humor and storytelling to lighten mood.
Ignores Krishna’s concerned calls to stop and walks away briskly despite others’ attempts to engage him.
Explains the tense situation with analogy and a clear narrative structure, showing his understanding and ability to communicate complex events simply.
Decides to walk away briskly despite Krishna's objections, ignoring his subordinate’s concerns, which might reflect confidence but also poor judgment or disregard for protocol.
Runs into the forest with the EVM to protect the election process despite being chased and endangered.
Accuses Atma Singh and his men of fraud directly and refuses to be intimidated.
Commands guns to be lowered and calls for calm dialogue with the tribal youth instead of violence.
Attempts to free himself violently and grabs a gun during scuffle.
Pounces on Romesh and grabs his gun during the scuffle, points it at Atma Singh to assert control.
Commands all guns to be lowered and calls the tribal youth to come peacefully, de-escalating the tense situation through assertive negotiation.
Maintains calm and practical approach despite intense conflict, directing others strategically (e.g., ordering Shambhu to set up the machine).
Insists on conducting voting despite threats, firmly directs others to carry out election process
Ignores concerns about safety and risks to others, insists on proceeding without addressing fears
Okays a brief pause in voting and waits patiently for five minutes before signing off and ending the election process.
Calmly tells Atma Singh to go ahead with arrest despite knowing it will happen; places gun down on the ground as a non-hostile gesture.
Questions Mishra persistently about procedure even when others remain silent or accept vague answers.
Demonstrates quick wit and confidence by handling Mishra's teasing calmly and responding cleverly about his name.
Accepts ridicule and does not get flustered when officers laugh, shows emotional steadiness.
Does not appear to take direct initiative to change the situation or challenge authority beyond questioning.
Is unable to impress Mishra or change his skeptical attitude through reasoning; Mishra remains unimpressed and treats Newton lightly.
Responds thoughtfully to Mishra's explanation and shows willingness to learn by engaging in the dialogue.
Admits he is still on probation and allocated as reserve for election duty, implying limited practical experience so far.
Expresses uncertainty or discomfort about the office environment ('Ajeeb sa mahoul hai'), indicating possible social or situational unease.
Forces a smile when Mishra laughs
Sits with family during arranged marriage meeting, listens quietly without interrupting
Does not show visible enthusiasm or active engagement during talk about embroidery and family
Works diligently in a dusty office while colleagues watch a cricket match, showing focus and commitment.
Looks disturbed while standing alone on the balcony, indicating introspection and possibly concern for others.
Prepares carefully by studying the Manual of Protocols and practicing using an apple to understand voting machine operation, demonstrating responsibility and sincerity.
Watches proceedings with the concentration of a benched player, indicating focus despite not being actively engaged.
Sits passively with other 'Reserve' officers without taking immediate initiative or asking questions.
Pays close attention to the situation at the collector’s table, showing situational awareness and concern.
Proceeds to the jungle area despite difficulties and danger, indicating responsibility but no explicit warmth toward others here.
Shakes hands with Sub Inspector Krishna Singh upon meeting.
Engages in light conversation and asks questions about safety and the environment kindly.
Asks practical questions about polling booth distance and confirms details with map, showing preparation and attention to duty.
Politely insists on doing his duty despite being told the election is boycotted and voter turnout will be zero.
Shakes head at Atma Singh's offer of whiskey, showing self-control and seriousness.
Cuts Loknath to maintain focus on duty, reflecting leadership and decisiveness.
Accepts Atma Singh’s assertion with a passive 'Theek hai phir likh ke dijiye' indicating some resignation or lack of challenge to the situation.
Questions Atma Singh about the need for bulletproof vest, showing awareness and willingness to understand situation risks.
Acknowledges shared discomfort with bulletproof vest but ultimately does not insist, reflecting some pragmatism but possible lack of assertiveness.
Relies on Atma Singh's assessment rather than strongly challenging the assertion about safety and equipment.
Silently contemplates while others wait and interact, shows patience and calm presence.
Walks to the group of Gondi youths stopped and questioned by SPOs.
Answers Atma Singh's questions respectfully despite awkwardness; tries to lighten the mood showing some empathy.
Expresses no personal opinion on sensitive topic to remain neutral; admits failure candidly.
Glares at Loknath when asked about political backing.
Questions Loknath sharply when asked about his lack of backing, showing confidence and unwillingness to accept status quo.
Observes and inquires carefully about the broken houses and absence of villagers, indicating attentiveness and investigative skill.
Expresses sadness and moral concern about the destruction caused by his own side, showing awareness but also emotional softness that might affect decision-making.
Examines the school premises meticulously, noticing bullet holes and Maoist graffiti, demonstrating observational skill and situational awareness.
Seems startled by graffiti but reacts by signaling others, showing presence of mind in an unexpected situation.
Checks the diagram of an ideal polling booth and notices the difference, then sets up tables and arranges the booth accordingly.
Ensures the EVM seal is intact and connects the units properly before the polling starts.
Presses the ON button of the EVM right on time, showing attentiveness to procedural details.
Keeps staring at the graffiti on the wall and looks disturbed, showing some internal distraction or concern.
Asks Priya about the survey and questions the accuracy of the data.
Newton is genuinely perplexed by Loknath's card explanation, showing some confusion.
Newton verbally challenges Loknath's nonsense, demanding respect and showing skepticism.
Looks at the crowd assembled at the school and asks about the absence of youth, showing concern and inclusive attitude.
Looks at Priya for translation multiple times when he does not understand the local language.
Has no answer when asked which candidate will get the right price for tendu patta.
Insists on continuing to wait for voters even when it seems unlikely anyone will come, emphasizing the importance of fairness.
Becomes visibly angry and frustrated when he perceives the election to be a meaningless formality, reacts sharply to Loknath.
Displays strong principles and a desire to uphold electoral integrity despite challenges and discouragement from others.
Fails to effectively convince or change the attitudes of colleagues like Loknath and Verma about the importance of fair elections.
Responds promptly to Priya's philosophical comment with a neutral, slightly impatient question 'point kya hai aapka?'
Encourages others to speak by saying 'Ab aap bhi kuch bol ke jaao!'
Does not engage deeply when Priya tries to offer emotional/philosophical insight, displays limited patience or understanding of subtle interpersonal cues
Runs with the EVM trying to escape capture, showing physical endurance and determination.
Freezes for a second upon seeing enemies approaching, indicating momentary hesitation.
Attempts to evade capture by running into dense forest showing quick decision making under pressure.
Is eventually caught, displaying a failure to outwit or outrun a large group of pursuers.
Insists he will document the fraud in his report despite threats, showing confidence and commitment to duty.
